“One can’t go out to give lessons without boots. I’m sick of it.”

“Don’t quarrel with your bread and butter.”

“They pay so little for lessons. What’s the use of a few coppers?” 

“Do you want a fortune all at once?”

“Yes, I want a fortune,” he replied firmly.

“Don’t be in such a hurry. Shall I get you the loaf or not?”

“As you please.”

“Ah, I forgot! A letter came for you yesterday.”

“A letter? From whom?”

“I can’t say. I gave three copecks to the postman for it. Will you pay me back?”

“Then bring it to me, for God’s sake!” 

A minute later, she returned. 

He turned pale. 

“Leave me alone! Here are your three copecks. Make haste and go!” 

The letter quivered in his hand.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov is anxious and excited about receiving a long-awaited letter from his mother, which stirs complex emotions within him.
